Mercy and justice must never be separated.

 Perhaps they are too closely allied to be separated. As an example, a man commits a heinous crime, for which he is sentenced to death. Justice? Perhaps.
 
 His sentence is commuted to life imprisonment for whatever reason. Justice? Perhaps. It's a question of fact and degree.
 
 Now the commutation of the death penalty to life imprisonment could be seen as an act of mercy, yet (for the sake of argument), justice has still been done. So in that sense, mercy is still justice in itself, but also a point on the justice scale.
 
 Which is better and why? That would depend on definition and perception, and likely to be totally subjective. The word 'better' would need defining/agreeing, and an assumption made that one was in fact 'better'. As a value system by which we live, most of us probably cleave to the notion of justice tempered with mercy, and in that sense the two are inseparable. There is therefore no reason to suppose that one is 'better' than the other, as each in isolation is likely to have disastrous consequences for the societal system in which it operates.

 I think this might better illustrate my point on why I think justice is better.
 
 Person A and B both commit the same crime above. Identical circumstances and motive.
 
 Person A is sentenced to death which is viewed as justice.
 
 Person B is also sentenced to death.
 
 Person B gets a commute to Life.
 This is viewed as an act of mercy.
 
 Person A doesn't (for what ever reason or lack thereof).
 
 We now no longer have justice as the punishment for the same crime isn't dealt with fairly.
 IMO, Justice should be dealt fairly and without bias. (that's why it's supposedly 'blind'.)
 
 If both suspects never recieve a commute then it's justice.
 If both suspects recieve this alleged act of mercy, it's still justice.
 HOWEVER, if all get the same act of mercy...who's to say it's really mercy at all?
 
 If all recieve a sever act of mercy (such as blanket pardons) then is justice really being served? Even if blanket mercy is applied commuting all death penalties to mercy...who's to say the death penalty is really being issued with any conviction or belief that it will be carried out when it's always going to be commuted to life. 
 In order for mercy to happen, the penalty that's deserved has to have a realistic chance of happening.
 
 IMO, perfect justice has no 'mercy'. 
 
 If whimsy is being used to determine who gets mercy, justice suffers. 
 
 If a well thought out justice system is in place, each person would get their just deserts relative to their actions, intent. Since this is fair, mercy wouldn't be needed.
 And if it's applied, it would cause suspicions on whether the system is actually fair or not.
 
 Hope that helps.
